oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Works Progress Administration schedule of hourly wages
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mimeographed WPA form listing occupational titles of skilled labor, hourly wages, hours of work, and monthly earnings. Occupations include artist, blacksmith, Braille proofreader, forelady and foreman (they earned the same), glazier, librarian, musician, photographer, plasterer, roofer, stone mason, teacher, terrazzo layer, and welder.

The Works Progress Administration (WPA, later Work Projects Administration) offered work to the unemployed on an unprecedented scale by spending money on a wide variety of programs, including highways and building construction, slum clearance, reforestation, and rural rehabilitation. A gigantic undertaking, it was inevitably attended by confusion, waste, and political favoritism, yet the "pump-priming" effect stimulated private business during the Depression and inaugurated reforms that states had been unable to subsidize. During 1935-1943, the WPA employed some 8.5 million people. (Information from Indiana University's online WPA exhibit)
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: New Deal, 1933-1939--Tennessee ; United States. Works Progress Administration; Professions
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Works Progress Aministration
